A Guide to the Norfolk (Va.) Dept. of Public Works, Architectural Drawings and Plans, 1899-1934

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: A Guide to the Norfolk (Va.) Dept. of Public Works, Architectural Drawings and Plans, 1899-1934
did.physdesc: 250 sheets of mostly blueprints, some India ink on linen, Diazoprint, and Sepia prints (61 x 91 cm. or smaller)

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Access to architectural and engineering plans and drawings of current governmental buildings requires a written request from the prospective user and written authorization from the appropriate authority within the agency occupying the facility. See Archives staff for further information.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Duplication of architectural and engineering plans and drawings of current governmental buildings may be prohibited. See LVA Archives staff for further information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Norfolk (Va.), Dept. of Public Works, Architectural drawings and plans, 1899-1934. Accession 35996, Local government records collection, The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Virginia.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Transfer from City of Norfolk, Department of Public Works, Norfolk, Va., n.d.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Department of Public Works was created when Norfolk adopted the a City Manager-style system of government in 1917. Section 52 of the city charter sets forth the administrative departments of government- Law, Public Works, Public Welfare, Public Safety, and Finance- under the City Manager. The Director of the Public Works Department was required to be an engineer by profession with experience in municipal engineering. The department would oversee the construction, improvement, repair, maintenance, and use of all public streets, sewers, culverts, canals, viaducts, public highways, sidewalks, drains, ditches, pumping stations, dams, wharves, landings, docks, parks, playgrounds, cemeteries, etc.
Within the Department of Public Works were the City Planning Commission and Board of Dock Commissioners. Walter H. Taylor, Jr. served as the first director of the department.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This accession consists of files of working drawings from the Norfolk Department of Public Works, presumably for demolished or otherwise obsolete structures. It documents a number of municipal projects from the early 1900s, such as armories, cemeteries, fire stations, hospitals, jails, markets, parks, police facilities, schools, and sewerage / drainage facilities. In many cases additional notations are made to the original plans to record modifications to structures.
Among the best documented project types are those for fire stations. Included are drawings of wharf facilities for the fire boat "Vulcan."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Alphabetically according to project type (Armories, Cemeteries, Fire Department, Hospitals, Jails, Markets, Miscellanious Drawings, Parks, Police Facilities, Schools, and Sewerage / Drainage Facilities) and chronologically there under.
